title-group.article-title: Foam-core, curved composite sandwich panels under blast

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Akron, Akron, OH, USA

author-notes.corresp: Michelle S Hoo Fatt, Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Akron, Akron, OH 044325-3903, USA. Email: hoofatt@uakron.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: An elastic-plastic model was developed for predicting the blast response of a foam-core, curved composite sandwich panel. A multi-layered approach was used to distinguish facesheets and core deformations. Core compressibility and transverse shear through the thickness were accounted for using linear displacement fields through the thickness. The predicted solution from the elastic-plastic model was shown to compare well with FEA from ABAQUS Implicit. A parametric study showed that blast resistance of the sandwich shell is increased by allowing cores to undergo plastic crushing. Very thick and shallow shells derive much of their resistance to blast from core crushing. Strong, dense foam cores did not increase the blast resistance of the curved sandwich panel but allowed facesheets to fracture while the core remained elastic.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Curved sandwich panels or sandwich shells consisting of fiber-reinforced polymer skins and polymer foam cores are used in navy ships. These hydro-dynamically shaped structures not only provide high specific stiffness and strength but are corrosion-free and low cost alternatives to their existing metal counterparts. When exposed to the high intensity loading of a blast, they could undergo dynamic instability or fracture under stable response if not properly designed. This paper presents an analytical model for the blast response of a curved, composite sandwich panel with polymeric foam core. The model will elucidate not only the dynamic response of the sandwich panel but address its ultimate failure and the energy absorption of its core up to the point of failure. A companion paper is devoted to the dynamic pulse buckling of the curved composite sandwich panel [1].

Over the past decade, several analytical solutions have been developed to address the blast response of composite sandwich shells [2–6]. Many of these solutions involve higher-order sandwich shell theory and incorporate compressible cores. Hohe and Librescu [3] used a multi-layered sandwich model, which distinguished between facesheets and core deformations, and a higher-order displacement field for capturing core compressibility to determine the response of a spherical sandwich cap under uniform pressure. This model was also used to address facesheet wrinkling, a local instability of the facesheet as opposed to a global snap-through buckling of the entire panel. Li et al. [5] presented a nonlinear compressible core model to capture the transient shock wave response of the individual facesheets and core of a shallow, simply supported composite sandwich shell. Using this model, they were able to show cavitation of the foam during the early-time sandwich panel response, involving the through-thickness shock wave. Li and Kardomateas [6] have also extended this theory to cylindrical sandwich shells with flexible core, thereby allowing one to differentiate deformations and stresses in individual facesheets and core. The above-mentioned papers are restricted to shallow shell assumptions, i.e. small strains and moderately large rotations. Furthermore, the sandwich core is elastic in these analytical formulations. In some instances, however, the core of the sandwich panel can experience plasticity due to permanent foam crushing. An elastic-plastic core may even be more representative of the blast behavior of foams used nowadays in composite sandwich construction. While the current design of a sandwich panel prohibits plastic crushing of the core, plastic core crushing becomes inevitable under very high intensity loading, such as a nearby blast.

Plastic foam crushing in composite sandwich structures under projectile impact has been addressed extensively in the past and only more recently for blast loading [7,8]. In Ref. 7, Hoo Fatt and Surabhi developed analytical models for the blast resistance and energy absorption of cylindrical, composite sandwich shells, while Hoo Fatt and Chapagain [8] presented an elastic-plastic sandwich panel model for simply supported, rectangular flat composite sandwich panels under uniformly distributed pressure pulse. This paper is an extension of the authors’ previous work on the topic.

sec.title: Problem formulation
sec.p:
Consider a single curvature, composite sandwich shell with facesheet thickness h and core thickness H, as shown in Figure 1. The mid-surfaces of the composite facesheets are defined with radius a1 and a2, and the shell subtends an angle θ0. It is fixed at the edges θ=0,θ0. Figure 1.
Geometry of composite sandwich shell.

The mass density of facesheets and core are ρf and ρc, respectively. The following assumptions concerning material behavior are made:
Foam cores do not experience appreciable crushing (core compression) before facesheet fracture so that they can be described as an elastic, perfectly plastic material. This assumption is generally applicable to composite sandwich panels with fiber-reinforced polymeric facesheets, which are brittle (fracture strains less than 5%).
There is perfect bonding between facesheets and core. The low strain deformation limits of the core will also ensure no interfacial cracking between facesheets and core.
Although many of the foams used in composite sandwich panels are transversely isotropic, the foam is assumed to be isotropic in this analysis. While transversely isotropic elastic properties of foam are readily available, transversely isotropic plastic flow properties are not. The model is therefore limited to the current state-of-the-art in crushable foam constitutive modeling.
Strain rate effects in both facesheet and core material behavior are neglected. Under blast loading, facesheet, and core materials may experience high strain rates, and both facesheet and core material behavior are best described by dynamic constitutive relations. In summary, the facesheets are therefore considered to be orthotropic, linear elastic-brittle material, while the foam core is idealized as isotropic, elastic, perfectly plastic material.

The length of the shell is very long and it is subjected to uniformly distributed pressure pulse (1)p(t)=p0(1-tΔT) where p0 is the peak pressure, ΔT is the load duration, and t is the time. The sandwich shell therefore deforms in a state of plane strain.

The facesheets are thin shells with radial deflections w1 and w2 and tangential deformations v1 and v2, as shown in Figure 1. These deformations are related to local coordinate systems θ,z1 and θ,z2, where z1 and z2 are defined at the mid-surface of the facesheets. The deformations at the mid-surface of the core are denoted w0 and v0 and likewise, these are defined with respect to θ,z. Specialized strain-displacement relations are derived in the following sections.

sec.title: Facesheet kinematics
sec.p: We introduce normalized facesheet deflections as follows: ζ1=w1/a1,ψ1=v1/a1,ζ2=w2/a2,ψ2=v2/a2. For fully clamped boundary condition of the sandwich shell, the facesheet deflections are subjected to ζ1=ζ2=0,∂ζ1/∂θ=∂ζ2/∂θ=0, and ψ1=ψ2=0 at θ=0,θ0. The boundary conditions of the facesheets are satisfied by the following Fourier series representations (2)ζ1=∑n=0∞en(1-cos2πθθ0)cosnπθθ0 (3)ψ1=∑n=1∞fnsinnπθθ0 (4)ζ2=∑n=0∞gn(1-cos2πθθ0)cosnπθθ0 (5)ψ2=∑n=1∞hnsinnπθθ0 where en,fn,gn, and hn are time-varying amplitudes. Other boundary conditions, such as pinned, will give rise to different Fourier series.

One of the reasons for considering the clamped boundary conditions in this paper is because these boundary conditions are easy to model in finite element analysis, which will be discussed later. Pinned boundary conditions on foam-core sandwich structure are very difficult to apply because failure will always take place at the pinned boundary of the soft core. Using roller boundary conditions for the curved sandwich panel is also not feasible if it is a deeply curved sandwich panel since membrane forces force the panel to slip out of the rollers.

Strains in the facesheet are based on large deflection, thin shell theory. The circumferential membrane and bending strains for a thin shell are taken from Refs. 9 and10 as (6)ɛθ1=ɛθm1+z1κθ1 and (7)ɛθ2=ɛθm2+z2κθ2 where the mid-surface strain and curvature in the outer (inner) facesheets are (8)ɛθm1=ψ'1-ζ1-ζ1ψ'1¯+12ζ'21 (9)κθ1=-1a1(ζ″1+ζ1¯) (10)ɛθm2=ψ'2-ζ2-ζ2ψ'2¯+12ζ'22 (11)κθ2=-1a2(ζ″2+ζ2¯) and [ ]' denotes derivative with respect to θ. The terms underlined in Equations (8) to (11) do not appear in shallow shell theory, but they are necessary for a deep shell.

sec.title: Simplified core kinematics
sec.p: Facesheets are assumed to be perfectly bonded to the core. The radial and tangential deformations of the core at the bond interface are thus continuous with the facesheet deformations. Radial deformations do not vary through the thickness of the facesheet so that radial deformations of the core at the bond interface are equal to the mid-surface radial deformation of the facesheets. A similar assumption is made for the core tangential deformations at the bond interface since variations in the tangential deformation from the mid-surface to the outer surfaces of the facesheets would be small because of the thinness of the facesheet to the core.

The radial and tangential deformations are assumed to vary linearly through the core. Following this assumption, the radial and tangential deformation at the core mid-surface are (12)w0=w1+w22 (13)v0=v1+v22
In addition to this, the core compresses with uniform radial strains (14)ɛr=w2-w1H and plane sections (transverse normals to the mid-surface) of the core rotate uniformly with angle (15)ϕ0=v2-v1H
The tangential and radial deformations in the core are (16)v(r,θ,t)=v0(θ,t)+zϕ0 (17)w(r,θ,t)=w0(θ,t)+zɛr
The above core mid-surface deflections are normalized as follows: ζ0=w0/a0,ψ0=v0/a0, where a0=(a1+a2)/2.

Higher-order functions have been used to describe core deformations in the past. Hohe and Librescu [3] used quadratic and cubic functions to describe the radial and tangential deformations of the core, while Li et al. [5] used a fourth-order and fifth-order polynomials to address out-of-plane and in-plane deformations of the core. Following small deflection, thick core shell theory, the strain–displacement relations are (18)ɛθ=ψ'0-ζ0+za0ϕ'0 and the transverse shear strains are (19)γrθ=-ζ'0-ϕ0+ψ0

Note that transverse shear strains are constant through the thickness, as in first-order shear deformation theory. These core strains can be expressed further in facesheet dimensionless variables as (20)ɛr=a1H(μζ2-ζ1) (21)ɛθ=(ψ'1+μψ'2)(1+μ)-(ζ1+μζ2)(1+μ)+za0a1H(μψ'2-ψ'1) (22)γrθ=-(ζ'1+μζ'2)(1+μ)-a1(μψ2-ψ1)H+(ψ1+μψ2)(1+μ) where μ=a2/a1 is the inner-to-outer radius ratio.

sec.title: Lagrange’s equations of motion
sec.p: The equations of motion governing the transient deformations of the shell are defined in normalized radial and tangential displacements and normalized time τ=ct/a1, where c=A22/(ρfh) is the wave speed and A22 is the membrane stiffness in the circumferential direction of the facesheet. In normalized time, the pressure pulse loading becomes (23)p(τ)=p0(1-ττ0) where τ0=cΔT/a1 is a normalized load duration.

The transient shell response is found from Lagrange’s equations of motion (24)ddτ(∂T∂q·n)-∂T∂qn+∂U∂qn=Qn where qn is a generalized coordinate, Qn is a generalized force, T is the kinetic energy, U is the strain energy, and [ ]•=∂[ ]/∂τ. Generalized forces Qn are obtained from virtual work δW(25)Qn=∂(δW)∂(δqn)
For uniformly distributed external pressure pulse (26)δW=∫0θ0p(τ)δζ1a12dθ=∑n=0∞Qnδen where (27)Qn=p(τ)a12∫0θ0(1-cos2πθθ0)cosnπθθ0dθ

The kinetic energy of the facesheets and core is as follows (28)Tf=A22a12∫0θ0[ζ·12+ψ·12+μ3(ζ·22+ψ·22)]dθ and (29)Tc=ρ¯A22a12∫0θ0[ζ·12+μ2ζ·22+2μζ·1ζ·2+43(ψ·12+μ2ψ·22+μψ·1ψ·2)]dθ where ρ¯=(1+μ)ρcH/(8ρfh).

sec.title: Elastic equations of motion
sec.p: The elastic strain energy of the facesheets is (30)Ui=12∫(A22ɛθmi2+D22κθi2)adθ, i=1,2 where A22 and D22 are the facesheet circumferential membrane and bending resistance, respectively. Substituting the facesheet strains given in Equations (8) to (11) into Equation (30) gives the strain energy of the outer and inner facesheets as (31)Uf=A22a12∫0θ0[(ψ'1-ζ1-ζ1ψ'1+12ζ'21)2+α12(ζ″1+ζ1)2]dθ +μA22a12∫0θ0[(ψ'2-ζ2-ζ2ψ'2+12ζ'22)2+α22(ζ″2+ζ2)2]dθ where α12=D22/(a12A22) and α22=D22/(a22A22). The core elastic strain energy is derived in Appendix 2 for the special case of plane strain as (32)Uce=ηA22a12∫0θ0{(μζ2-ζ1)2+ω2(ψ'1+μψ'2-ζ1-μζ2)2 +ω23Λ(μψ'2-ψ'1)[(-ψ'1-μψ'2+ζ1+μζ2)+Λ(μψ'2-ψ'1)] +β26Λ(μζ2-ζ1)[6Λ(ψ'1+μψ'2-ζ1-μζ2)-(μψ'2-ψ'1)] +γ2[-ζ'1-μζ'2-2Λ(μψ2-ψ1)+ψ1+μψ2]2}dθ where Λ=(1+μ)/(2(1-μ)), and η,ω2,β2, and γ2 are elastic constants of the foam defined in Appendix 2.

Coupled elastic equations of motion result from satisfying Lagrange’s equation of motion as follows: (33)∑m=0N[2(1+ρ¯)e··m+2μλg··m] f∧0(m,n)+Pe=Q¯n (34)∑m=0N[2μ(ρ¯+μ)g··m+2μe··m] f∧0(m,n)+Pg=0 (35)[23(3+4ρ¯) f··n+43μh··n]θ02+Pf=0 (36)[23μ(3μ2+4ρ¯)h··n+43μf··n]θ02+Ph=0 where n is the particular mode of the Fourier series, N is the chosen number of terms in the Fourier series, Q¯n is a normalized load, Pe,Pg,Pf,Ph are elastic spring forces and f∧0 is given by (37)f∧0(m,n)=∫0θ0(1-cos2πθθ0)2cosmπθθ0cosnπθθ0dθ

In Equations (33) and (34), there is coupling not only between each deformation mode but also between mode numbers of the same deformation mode. The normalized external load is (38)Q¯n=2p¯(τ)∫R(1-cos2πθθ0)cosnπθθ0dθ where p¯(τ)=a1p0A22(1-ττ0) is the normalized pressure pulse loading. The elastic spring forces Pe,Pg,Pf,Ph result from taking derivatives of the strain energy in terms of the generalized coordinates. Explicit equations for them are not given here because they are very lengthy.

sec.title: Elastic-plastic equations of motion
sec.p: For high enough pressure pulse amplitude, the core may yield and undergo plasticity. The elastic-plastic behavior of the core is described as crushable foam with isotropic hardening [11]. The condition for initial core yielding under plane strain conditions is given by the yield condition (39)f=σ∧-σ0=0 where σ0 is the flow stress and the effective stress σ∧ is given by (40)σ∧2=1[1+(αp3)2](σe2+αp2σm2) where αp=3/2, assuming the foam plastic Poisson’s ratio is approximately zero, and the mean stress σm and von Mises stress σe. Under plane strain conditions and elastic conditions (41)σm=(1+ν)3(σr+σθ) (42)σe=12{(σr-σθ)2+[(1-ν)σr-σθ]2 +[(1-ν)σθ-σr]2+6τrθ2}12 where ν is the elastic Poisson’s ratio. Substituting Equations (41) and (42) in Equation (39) gives the effective stress of the foam at initial yield as (43)σ∧=[σr2+σθ2+ν2(σr+σθ)2+2τrθ2]12

Subsequent plastic flow is determined by an associated flow rule. Under plane strain, the elastic-plastic stress–strain relations are generally not ideally plastic (constant stress) for a material that is elastic-perfectly plastic under uniaxial stress [12]. Incremental stress–strain relations can be derived for the foam and the resulting strain hardening plastic stress–strain curve must be integrated from it. This approach will not be used here. Instead we neglect strain hardening of the foam due to plane strain constraint and assume that continued plastic flow is at a constant stress. A material point in the foam that has yielded will exhibit the stress–strain curve described by the solid line in Figure 2. Equations (39) and (43) are used to determine plastic regions in the foam. These plastic regions are more likely to develop near the clamp edges where transverse shear stresses are high, as indicated in Figure 3. Although the hoop strains in Equation (21) contain a bending strain that is linear in z- or the through-thickness coordinate, this term is negligible compared with the hoop membrane strain, as well as the radial and transverse shear strains. As such, foam stresses do not vary through the thickness and are primarily a function of θ. Figure 2.
Representation of nonlinear elastic strain energy density in an elastic perfectly plastic material (solid line).
Figure 3.
Elastic and plastic regions in the foam.

Foam plasticity is accounted for by assuming non-linear elasticity. The strain energy density for the foam that is undergoing yielding is calculated from the areas under the stress–strain curve shown in Figure 2 (44)UOACD=UOBD-UABC

The hatched region in Figure 2 is represented as negative area or strain energy density in Equation (44). In terms of total strain energy, the foam (45)Ucep=12∫Ve(C11ɛr2+2C12ɛθɛr+C11ɛθ2+C66γrθ2)dV +12∫Vp[C11ɛr2+2C12ɛθɛr+C11ɛθ2+C66γrθ2 -C11(ɛr-ɛr0)2-2C12(ɛθ-ɛθ0)(ɛr-ɛr0) -C11(ɛθ-ɛθ0)2-C66(γrθ-γrθ0)2]dV where Ve and Vp are the volumes of the elastic and plastic regions (see Figure 3). The above expression is expanded in terms of foam strains defined in Equations (20) to (22) as (46)Ucep=ηA22a12∫Re{(μζ2-ζ1)2+ω2(ψ'1+μψ'2-ζ1-μζ2)2 +ω23Λ(μψ'2-ψ'1)[(-ψ'1-μψ'2+ζ1+μζ2)+Λ(μψ'2-ψ'1)] +β26Λ(μζ2-ζ1)[6Λ(ψ'1+μψ'2-ζ1-μζ2)-(μψ'2-ψ'1)] +γ2[-ζ'1-μζ'2-2Λ(μψ2-ψ1)+ψ1+μψ2]2}dθ +η0A22a12∫Rp{μζ2-ζ1+ω02(ψ'1+μψ'2-ζ1-μζ2)+ω026Λ(ψ'1-μψ'2) +γ02[-ζ'1-μζ'2-2Λ(μψ2-ψ1)+ψ1+μψ2]}dθ where Re and Rp are angular elastic and plastic regions and η0,ω02,γ02 are plastic constants of the foam defined in Appendix 3.

Coupled elastic-plastic equations of motion result from satisfying Lagrange’s equation of motion (47)∑m=0N[2(1+ρ¯)e··m+2μλg··m]f∧0(m)+Pep=Q¯n-Qde (48)∑m=0N[2μ(ρ¯+μ)g··m+2μe··m]f∧0(m)+Pgp=-Qdg (49)[23(3+4ρ¯)f··n+43μh··n]θ02+Pfp=-Qdf (50)[23μ(3μ2+4ρ¯)h··n+43μf··n]θ02+Php=-Qdh where elastic spring forces are Pep,Pgp,Pfp,Php and plastic damping forces are Qde,Qdg,Qdf,Qdh. The elastic spring forces and damping forces result from the first and last integrals of Equation (46), respectively. They are described by very lengthy equations and are not shown for brevity. Since the elastic strain energy is integrated only over the elastic core regions, Pep,Pgp,Pfp,Php are smaller than Pe,Pg,Pf,Ph. The plastic damping forces Qde,Qdg,Qdf,Qdh are introduced on the right-hand side of the equations of motion to indicate that they retard deformation.

sec.title: An example
sec.p:
The composite sandwich shell considered has dimensions h=5 mm, H=25 mm, a1=396 mm, a2=365 mm, and θ0=90∘. The mean radius-to-thickness ratio of this curved sandwich shell is 10.71, which implies a rather thick shell. It is made with 0/90 woven E-glass/vinyl ester facesheets and a Divinycell PVC H200 foam core, with properties of the facesheet and core listed in Table 1. The shell is subjected to the uniformly distributed pressure pulse described in Equation (1), where p0=2.2 MPa and ΔT=1 ms. Table 1.
Material properties of 0/90 woven roving E-glass/vinyl ester and different foams.
E-glass/vinyl ester Divinycell H30 Divinycell H100 Divinycell H200 Klegecell R300 Divinycell HCP100
Density (kg/m3) 1391.3 36 100 200 300 400
E11 (+) (GPa) 17 0.044 0.149 0.277 – –
E22 (+) (GPa) 17 0.044 0.149 0.277 – –
E33 (+) (GPa) 7.48 0.044 0.149 0.277 – –
E11 (−) (GPa) 19 0.027 0.105 0.293 0.338 0.340
E22 (−) (GPa) 19 0.027 0.105 0.293 0.338 0.340
E33 (−) (GPa) – 0.027 0.105 0.293 0.338 0.340
ν12 = ν21 0.13 0.25 0.31 0.3 0.23 0.3
ν13 = ν23 0.28 0.25 0.31 0.3 0.23 0.3
ν31 = ν32 0.12 0.25 0.31 0.3 0.23 0.3
G12 = G21 (GPa) 4.0 0.013 0.0438 0.110 0.123 0.131
G23 = G32 (GPa) 1.73 0.013 0.0438 0.110 0.123 0.131
G13 = G31 (GPa) 1.73 0.013 0.0438 0.110 0.123 0.131
q (MPa) – 0.3 1.66 4.35 7.8 10.3
γf – 0.09 0.4 0.45 0.27 0.35
XT, σ10 (+) (MPa) 270 0.57 3.2 6.4 – –
XC, σ10 (−) (MPa) 200 0.29 1.53 4.36 – –
YT, σ20 (+) (MPa) 270 0.57 3.5 6.4 – –
YC, σ20 (−) (MPa) 200 0.29 1.53 4.36 – –
SL, τ120 = τ210 (MPa) 40 0.35 1.47 3.86 – 7.44
ST,τ13f = τ310 (MPa) 31.6 0.35 1.47 3.86 – 7.44
ST,τ230 = τ320 (MPa) 31.6 0.35 1.47 3.86 – 7.44

A MATLAB program was written to solve coupled equations of motion for time-varying amplitudes of the Fourier series in Equations (2) to (5), i.e. coefficients en,fn,gn, and hn It was found that converged solutions for the deformations could be obtained by setting n = 16 in the Fourier series. The radial deformation of the sandwich mid-plane is shown at various times in Figure 4. Stresses at the sandwich mid-plane were calculated at 0.13 ms, which is the time just before the onset of plastic flow, and are shown in Figure 5. It is very apparent that for this rather thick shell, foam plasticity will begin near the clamped boundaries where all stress components in the foam are at their greatest. Also note that the magnitudes of the peak radial, hoop, and axial stresses are of the same order of magnitude as the peak transverse shear stress. A sandwich theory that ignores radial stress in the core would therefore be inaccurate in predicting the behavior of a thick curved sandwich panel. The effective stress σ∧, as expressed by Equation (43), was calculated for the corresponding times given in Figure 4, and the distribution of the effective stress in the mid-plane of the core is plotted in Figure 6 to indicate that plasticity begins near the clamped ends at about 0.13 ms. This plastic region grows until about 0.35 ms when the facesheet ruptures. A condition for facesheet rupture will be given later. Finite element analysis predictions of the corresponding variables in the composite sandwich shell are also shown in Figures 4 to 6 and discussed below. Figure 4.
Radial displacements taken at mid-surface of sandwich shell.
Figure 5.
Stress variation along the mid-surface of core at t = 0.13 ms, right before core yielding.
Figure 6.
Effective stress at mid-surface of sandwich shell (core becomes plastic right after t = 0.13 ms).

sec.title: Finite element analysis
sec.p:
Finite element analysis with ABAQUS Standard Version 6.9 (Ref. 13) was done in order to corroborate solutions with the analytical model. The FEA model is shown in Figure 7. Continuum plane strain four node elements (CPE4) were chosen for both facesheets and core. The facesheet was modeled as linear elastic, orthotropic material, and the core was modeled by using crushable foam with isotropic hardening [11,13]. Plasticity properties for the Divinycell H200 foam were taken from Mines and Alias [14]. Figure 7.
Finite element model of composite sandwich shell.

Results from the ABAQUS Standard are compared to the results from MATLAB in Figures 4 to 6. The numerical implementation in ABAQUS Standard involved Dynamic, Implicit analysis. The direct-integration method provided for Dynamic, Implicit analysis in ABAQUS Standard is the Hilber-Hughes Taylor operator, which is an extension of the trapezoidal rule. Automatic time increment with specified half-step residual was used. A parametric study was done to determine the appropriate size of the half-step residual that would yield accurate results. No numerical damping was specified in the problem.

Good agreement was found between the MATLAB and FEA solutions in all cases. There is better agreement in mid-surface radial deformation of the foam (Figure 4) and effective stress (Figure 6) when the core is elastic than when it is elastic-plastic. This is because of the approximate nature of the calculated elastic-plastic strain energy in core. Also, stresses near the clamped edge (Figure 5) are not evaluated as well as at other locations even with a 16-term Fourier series in the model. The solution from the elastic-plastic model is within 5% of the FEA radial deformations and 15% of the FEA stresses. Fourier series solutions converge more rapidly for deflections than stresses because stresses are calculated from strains, which are expressed in terms of derivatives of the deflections. The above discrepancies are not uncommon in analytical solutions using the Fourier series approach.

sec.title: Sandwich panel failure
sec.p:
Sandwich panel failure may occur in the modes shown in Figures 8(a) and (b). Facesheet failure is primarily due to compressive hoop stresses because of the initial shell curvature. As indicated in Figure 8(a), it is the distal or inner facesheet, with a smaller radius of curvature and higher circumferential strain than the loaded or outer facesheet, that first experiences compressive facesheet failure near the clamped boundary. If the foam is very weak or the facesheet is very strong, the core of the curved sandwich panel can fail in a transverse shear mode, which is also shown in Figure 8(a). Finally, a very strong core and facesheet may prevent the failure modes shown in Figure 8(a), but the curved sandwich panel may still fail due to dynamic pulse buckling [15] as described in Figure 8(b). This failure mode of composite shells subjected to external blast has received some attention in recent years [9,16] and will be dealt with in a companion paper [1]. The following section describes simply equations that can be used for facesheet and core failure modes. Figure 8.
Failure modes of sandwich shell: (a) facesheet and foam fracture during stable response and (b) dynamic instability of facesheets.

sec.title: Facesheet failure
sec.p: The modified Hashin–Rotem criteria are used to examine lamina failure of the woven roving E-glass/vinyl ester [17]. According to the modified Hashin–Rotem failure criteria, the failure of the composite occurs when (51)|σx|XT=1 ifσx>0 or|σx|XC=1 ifσx<0 (52)|σθ|YT=1 ifσθ>0 or|σθ|YC=1 ifσθ<0 (53)|τθ|SL=1

For an orthotropic shell, the relationship between the principal stresses and strains is given by (54){σxσθτxθ}=[Q¯11Q¯120Q¯12Q¯22000Q¯66]{ɛxɛθγxθ} where Q¯11=E11/(1-ν12ν21),Q¯22=E22/(1-ν12ν21),Q¯12=ν12E22/(1-ν12ν21), andQ¯66=G12 and.In the plane strain problem, the stresses in the shell are reduced to (55)σx=Q¯12ɛθ (56)σθ=Q¯22ɛθ
Since Q¯22>Q¯12,σθ>σx, failure of the shell will occur in tangential direction. Substituting Equation (56) into Equation (52), one gets (57)Q¯22ɛθYT=1 ifσθ>0 and (58)Q¯22ɛθYC=1 ifσθ<0
Thus, the value of the hoop strain at which failure occurs is given by (59)ɛf=min(YT,Yc)Q¯22
The above expression describes the maximum allowable strain based on a Hashin–Rotem composite failure criterion.

sec.title: Core shear fracture
sec.p: Although the core fracture is of a mixed mode type involving transverse shear and hoop, radial and axial compression, a simple criterion for the onset of core shear failure is to set the transverse shear strain in the core equal to the core transverse fracture strain,γf. Since the transverse shear strain in the core is given by Equation (22), the criterion for core shear fracture becomes (60)γf=-(ζ'1+μζ'2)(1+μ)-a1(μψ2-ψ1)H+(ψ1+μψ2)(1+μ)

sec.title: Dissipated plastic work
sec.p:
If the foam core crushes and experiences plasticity before sandwich panel failure, the plastic work dissipated in the core may be approximated. In Figure 9(a), plastic regions extend over angular regions with extent Δθ. The stress–strain behavior at the initial yield points, C1 and C2, is shown in Figure 9(b), where ɛijf denotes the final strain components at fracture and the onset of elastic unloading. Assuming that these strain components linearly decrease from ɛijf to ɛij0 at the elastic and plastic boundaries, one gets the following expression for the energy dissipated by plastic work up to shell failure (61)Ed=12[σr0(ɛrf-ɛr0)+σθ0(ɛθf-ɛθ0)+τrθ0(γrθf-γrθ0)](a12-a22)Δθ Figure 9.
Plastic work dissipated in core at failure: (a) plastic regions and (b) stress–strain curve at initial yield points.

sec.title: Parametric study
sec.p: A parametric study was used to determine the mode of failure and energy dissipation of curved sandwich panels. The effect of three parameters, sandwich radius-to-thickness ratio, angular extent, and foam core, is discussed below. The facesheets are made of 0/90 woven E-glass/vinyl ester, with properties given in Table 1, in all the cases discussed below.

sec.title: Radius-to-thickness ratio
sec.p:
The mean radius-to-thickness ratio of the sandwich shell will determine the global stiffness and strength of the panel. This parametric study was done on a composite sandwich shell with Divinycell H200 core, h=5 mm, H=25 mm, θ0=90∘, and various facesheet radii. Figure 10 shows that the blast resistance decreases as the radius-to-thickness ratio increases, as to be expected since the sandwich panel loses global bending resistance as this ratio increases. What is also shown in Figure 10 is that the amount of plastic work dissipated in the core before failure reaches a value of about 20 J when the radius-to-thickness ratio is high, over 30. For high radius-to-thickness ratios, the curved sandwich panel is becoming more of a thin shell, in which hoop or membrane stresses dominate over radial stresses in the foam. Figure 10.
Variation of blast resistance and energy absorption with radius-to-thickness ratio.

sec.title: Angular extent/shallowness
sec.p:
Many analytical models for double curvature sandwich shells are based on so-called shallow shell theory in order to simplify shell kinematics. A shallow shell is defined when the angular extent θ0 is less than 25°. A parametric study was done to examine what happens when the curved sandwich panel is made into a shallow sandwich shell. A composite sandwich shell with Divinycell H200 core, h=5 mm, H=25 mm, a1=1,437 mm, a2=1,407 mm and various angular extent θ0 is considered. Figure 11 shows that for deep shells, the blast resistance does not vary substantially, but it increases as θ0 decreases in the case of shallow shells. Also the plastic work dissipation in the core of a shallow shell is substantially higher than in a deep shell. Figure 11.
Variation of blast resistance and energy absorption with angular extent.

sec.title: Foam core
sec.p: Both thick and thin composite sandwich shells are considered in this parametric study. Each sandwich shell is composed of facesheets made of 0/90 woven E-glass/vinyl ester and thickness h=5 mm. The cores in them are composed of the various foams listed in Table 1 and have thickness H=25 mm. Foam properties listed in Table 1 were obtained from Refs. 18–22. The shear strains at fracture for the foams were specifically taken from Diab [22].

The thick sandwich shell considered has dimensions a1=396 mm, a2=365 mm, and θ0=90∘. This gives a sandwich radius-to-thickness ratio a0/(2h+H)=10.7,which means it is fairly thick. Figure 12(a) indicates that the highest load is sustained by the sandwich shell with the Divinycell H200 foam core. This sandwich shell and those with Divinycell H30 and H100 foams underwent plasticity before sandwich panel failure (see Figure 12(b)). The sandwich panel with Divinycell H30 core actually failed by core shear fracture, while all the other sandwich panels failed by facesheet fracture. The sandwich shells with stiffer and stronger foams, Klegecell R300 and Divinycell HCP100, remained fully elastic and absorbed no energy up to the point of facesheet fracture. Figure 12.
Thick sandwich shell with a0/(2h+H)=10.7 and θ0=90°: (a) blast resistance and (b) energy dissipation.

The thin sandwich shell considered has dimensions a1=1437.6 mm, a2=1407.2, mm and θ0=30∘. This gives a sandwich radius-to-thickness ratio a0/(2h+H)=40,which makes it a thin sandwich shell. Figure 13(a) and (b) shows the blast resistance and energy absorption associated with failure for the thin sandwich shell. While the failure pressure loads are all lower than the thick sandwich shells, similar conclusions are drawn. The panel that was most blast resistant is still the one with the Divinycell H200 core, and it underwent plastic core crushing although not as much plastic work was absorbed during failure. The panel with Divinycell H30 underwent plasticity and core shear failure, while the panels with strong cores, Klegecell R300 and Divinycell HCP100, experienced no plastic core crushing before facesheet fracture. Figure 13.
Thin sandwich shell with a0/(2h+H)=40and θ0=30°: (a) blast resistance and (b) energy dissipation.

This parametric study indicates that contrary to popular belief, stiffer and stronger cores do not increase the blast resistance of a curved, composite sandwich shells. The most blast resistant curved sandwich panel with Divinycell H200 core underwent some, but not significant, plastic core crushing. In a related study on flat sandwich panels [8], a similar conclusion was made but only on a per unit weight basis for the entire panel.

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: An elastic-plastic model was developed for predicting the blast response of a foam-core, curved composite sandwich panel. The curved sandwich panel was described with a single radius of curvature, being clamped along the axis of zero curvature. It was also long enough along the clamped edge to be in a state of plane strain. A multi-layered approach was used to distinguish facesheets and core deformations. Core compressibility and transverse shear through the thickness were accounted for using linear displacement fields through the thickness. The predicted solution from the elastic-plastic model was shown to compare well with FEA from ABAQUS Implicit.

A parametric study showed that blast resistance of the sandwich shell is increased by allowing cores to undergo plastic crushing. Very thick and shallow shells derive much of their resistance to blast from core crushing. Strong, dense foam cores did not increase the blast resistance of the curved sandwich panel but allowed facesheets to fracture while the core remained elastic. Shells with strong cores and very thin facesheets may be susceptible to local pulse buckling or facesheet wrinkling, and this would be addresss in a companion paper.

ack.p: The authors would like to acknowledge financial support from Dr Yapa Rajapakse at the Office of Naval Research under Grant N00014-11-1-0485.

sec.title: Elastic strain energy of core
sec.p: Under plane strain conditions, the elastic stress–strain constitutive equations in the core are (62){σrσθτrθ}=[C11C120C12C11000C66]{ɛrɛθγrθ} where C11=2G+λ,C12=λ,C66=G,λ=νE/((1+ν)(1-2ν)), and G,E, and ν are the shear modulus, Young’s modulus, and Poisson’s ratio, respectively. The axial stress is (63)σx=ν(σr+σθ)
The elastic strain energy in the core is given by (64)Uce=12∫(σrɛr+σθɛθ+τrθγrθ)dV where dV=rdrdθ. Substituting Equation (62) into Equation (64) gives (65)Uce=12∫(C11ɛr2+2C12ɛθɛr+C11ɛθ2+C66γrθ2)dV
The core strains are (66)ɛr=a1H(μζ2-ζ1) (67)ɛθ=(ψ'1+μψ'2)(1+μ)-(ζ1+μζ2)(1+μ)+za0a1H(μψ'2-ψ'1) (68)γrθ=-(ζ'1+μζ'2)(1+μ)-a1(μψ2-ψ1)H+(ψ1+μψ2)(1+μ)
The first term of Equation (65) is (69)Uc1=12C11a12Λ∫0θ0(μζ2-ζ1)2dθ whereΛ=(1+μ)/(2(1-μ)).
The second term of Equation (65) is (70)Uc2=C12a0a1(1+μ)∫0θ0(μζ2-ζ1)(μψ'2+ψ'1-μζ2-ζ1)dθ +C12a12H12a0∫0θ0(μζ2-ζ1)(ψ'1-μψ'2)dθ
The third term of Equation (65) is (71)Uc3=12C11a0H(1+μ)2∫0θ0(ψ'1+μψ'2-ζ1-μζ2)2dθ +C11a1H212a0(1+μ)∫0θ0(ψ'1+μψ'2-ζ1-μζ2)(ψ'1-μψ'2)dθ +C11a12H24a0∫0θ0(μψ'2-ψ'1)2dθ
The last term of Equation (65) is (72)Uc4=12C66a0H(1+μ)2∫0θ0[-μζ'2-ζ'1-2Λ(μψ2-ψ1)+μψ2+ψ1]2dθ

Combining Equations (69) to (72) gives (73)Uce=ηA22a12∫0θ0{(μζ2-ζ1)2+ω2(ψ'1+μψ'2-ζ1-μζ2)2 +ω23Λ(μψ'2-ψ'1)[(-ψ'1-μψ'2+ζ1+μζ2)+Λ(μψ'2-ψ'1)] +β26Λ(μζ2-ζ1)[6Λ(ψ'1+μψ'2-ζ1-μζ2)-(μψ'2-ψ'1)] +γ2[-ζ'1-μζ'2-2Λ(μψ2-ψ1)+ψ1+μψ2]2}dθ where η=C11a1ΛA22 ω2=14Λ2 β2=C12C11Λ γ2=C664Λ2C11

sec.title: Nonlinear elastic strain energy of core
sec.p: The following nonlinear strain energy expression can be used to determine the elastic-plastic motion using Lagrange’s method (74)Ucep=12∫Re(C11ɛr2+2C12ɛθɛr+C11ɛθ2+C66γrθ2)dV +12∫Rp[C11ɛr2+2C12ɛθɛr+C11ɛθ2+C66γrθ2-C11(ɛr-ɛr0)2 -2C12(ɛθ-ɛθ0)(ɛr-ɛr0)-C11(ɛθ-ɛθ0)2-C66(γrθ-γrθ0)2]dV

The first integrand is the same as in purely elastic response. Hence (75)12∫Re(C11ɛr2+2C12ɛθɛr+C11ɛθ2+C66γrθ2)dV=ηA22a12∫θe{(μζ2-ζ1)2+ω2(ψ'1+μψ'2-ζ1-μζ2)2 +ω23Λ(μψ'2-ψ'1)[(-ψ'1-μψ'2+ζ1+μζ2)+Λ(μψ'2-ψ'1)] +β26Λ(μζ2-ζ1)[6Λ(ψ'1+μψ'2-ζ1-μζ2)-(μψ'2-ψ'1)] +γ2[-ζ'1-μζ'2-2Λ(μψ2-ψ1)+ψ1+μψ2]2}dθ

Expansion of the second integrand gives (76)12∫Rp[C11ɛr2+2C12ɛθɛr+C11ɛθ2+C66γrθ2 -C11(ɛr-ɛr0)2-2C12(ɛθ-ɛθ0)(ɛr-ɛr0)-C11(ɛθ-ɛθ0)2-C66(γrθ-γrθ0)2]dV =12∫Rp[2C11ɛr0ɛr+2C12ɛθ0ɛr+2C12ɛr0ɛθ+2C11ɛθ0ɛθ+2Gγrθ0γrθ -C11ɛr02-2C12ɛθ0ɛr0-C11ɛθ02-C66γrθ02]dV

In this expression, the constant terms C11ɛr02,2C12ɛθ0ɛr0,C11ɛθ02,C66γrθ02 can be neglected because they will vanish when Ucep is made derivative in Lagrange’s equation of motion. Hence Equation (76) can be expressed as (77)12∫Rp[2C11ɛr0ɛr+2C12ɛθ0ɛr+2C12ɛr0ɛθ+2C11ɛθ0ɛθ+2C66γrθ0γrθ]dV =η0A22a12∫θp{μζ2-ζ1+ω02(ψ'1+μψ'2-ζ1-μζ2)+ω026Λ(ψ'1-μψ'2) +γ02[-ζ'1-μζ'2-2Λ(μψ2-ψ1)+ψ1+μψ2]}dθ where η0=2a0A22(C11ɛr0+C12ɛθ0) ω02=12Λ(C11ɛθ0+C12ɛr0)(C11ɛr0+C12ɛθ0) γ02=12ΛC66γrθ0(C11ɛr0+C12ɛθ0)

Substituting Equations (75) to (77) into Equation (74) gives (78)Ucep=ηA22a12∫θe{(μζ2-ζ1)2+ω2(ψ'1+μψ'2-ζ1-μζ2)2 +ω23Λ(μψ'2-ψ'1)[(-ψ'1-μψ'2+ζ1+μζ2)+Λ(μψ'2-ψ'1)] +β26Λ(μζ2-ζ1)[6Λ(ψ'1+μψ'2-ζ1-μζ2)-(μψ'2-ψ'1)] +γ2[-ζ'1-μζ'2-2Λ(μψ2-ψ1)+ψ1+μψ2]2}dθ +η0A22a12∫θp{μζ2-ζ1+ω02(ψ'1+μψ'2-ζ1-μζ2)uad+ω026Λ(ψ'1-μψ'2)+γ02[-ζ'1-μζ'2-2Λ(μψ2-ψ1)+ψ1+μψ2]}dθ
